text:
FREDRICKA WHITFIELD:
Iran now saying

it will ban US citizens
from entering the country

in response to President
Trump's new travel ban

involving Muslim nationals
out of seven nations.

I want to bring in CNN Senior
International Correspondent
Ben Wedeman from Istanbul.

So how is all of
this being received?

BEN WEDEMAN: Well,
not surprisingly,

the Iranian government
has reacted angrily

to this temporary ban,
the foreign ministry
putting out a statement.

And I'll read a
bit of it for you.

He said-- the statement says,
"This is an obvious insult

to the Islamic world and in
particular to the great nation
of Iran."

It also calls this "a
gift to extremists,"

which is something I've heard
from people in Iraq as well,

as well as Syrian
refugees here in Turkey.

It appears that this measure to
heighten the level of security

as sort of the measures
against people trying to get

to the United States--
refugees and others--

is a bit like taking
a sledgehammer
to fix a Swiss watch.

Certainly, there's
obviously ways
to improve the current system.

But it appears that many
people are perceiving

this executive order as simply
throwing it out the window
altogether.

And already we're starting
to see the reaction.

I've also heard from
parliamentarians in Baghdad

who say they would like to
implement similar measures,
as well.

The Iraqi government
hasn't make--
made a decision on this.

But it's highly problematic
when you consider, Fredricka,

that there are more than 5,000
US military personnel currently

in Iraq supporting
the Iraqi government
in its war to drive ISIS--

the terrorists-- out
of their country.

FREDRICKA WHITFIELD:
And-- and that

was an agreement largely
crafted by the Iraqi government.
And that is the difference, too.
BEN WEDEMAN: Yes.

And, obviously, for
many Iraqis, this

is a sort of-- source
of great consternation

because they see themselves
as being in the front line

in the war against
terrorism, against ISIS,

keeping in mind that
thousands of Iraqis
have died fighting ISIS.

And now they find themselves
being put, in a sense,

in the same trench
as ISIS itself.
